--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> Hi Mitchell, concentration does sound like a very
> interesting problem for an ANN.  It is probably
> quite difficult since it involves long term 
> accurate and discrete memory.  But the input
> representaiton,
> i.e. how you represent the cards to the network,
> is probably a major issue.  And it's not clear what
> the right way would be, so it needs careful
> consideration
> since some representations are likely impossible for
> an ANN to
> deal with.  But I think it's quite an interesting
> experiment,
> and I hope someone tries it out.  I am unfortunately
> 
> involved in plugging NEAT into too many experiments
> at
> the present time, but if you put your code in the
> files section of this board, hopefully someone will
> take
> interest.  If I find time I might play with it
> myself.

OK, done.  There are two ASCII files, concen.c &
consubs.c.  They are to be compiled and linked with
any C compiler.  Yes, I think this will be very
difficult for most ANN topologies.  I expect to start
with a deck of only 4 cards of 2 different kinds!
But I want to see if we can develop ANNs that truly
function as universal Turing machines.  If I can't
succeed with the usual ANN topologies I thought I
would make a memory peripheral that the ANN can use.

About the inputs & outputs, I'm envsioning 2 input
lines for every card position.  One would be binary to
tell whether there is a card there or not.  The other
would go through steps of 1/N to identify the card.
Or I might use all binary with N+1 lines for each
position.  So a deck of 6 cards of 3 kinds would have
24 binary input lines.

Outputs would be one for each card position, the one
that goes high indicates which card to expose.

m
